verse: Meanwhile, Ben-hadad, Aram’s king, gathered his entire army to lay siege to Samaria. He was accompanied by 32 other kings as well as a large group of horses and chariots. He waged war against Samaria.
Ben-hadad then instructed his messengers to travel to see Ahab, Israel’s king, inside the city.
The messengers came back to Ahab and gave him a new message.
Israel’s king gathered up all the elders of Israel and explained the situation to them.
Ahab then gave a new message for the messengers to take back to Ben-hadad.

When Ben-hadad received this message, he was drinking with other kings in the camp. He gave urgent instructions to his servants: “Get the army ready immediately. I’ve had enough of Ahab.” The army prepared for battle against the city.
About this time, a prophet entered into the presence of Ahab, who was Israel’s king.
Ahab then gathered up all the young officers of the provincial leaders, and there were 232 in all. Then he gathered together everyone else, including the Israelites. There were 7,000 in all.
They set out at noon. While they did this, Ben-hadad was drinking alcohol excessively in the camp with the other 32 kings who served him.
The young officers of the provincial leaders approached first. When a patrol of scouts Ben-hadad had sent out came back, they reported to him.
The young officers of the provincial leaders had left the city with their army following them.
They proceeded to crush each man they faced. All the Arameans ran for their lives, and the Israelites went after them. Ben-hadad, Aram’s king, escaped on horseback with some of his horsemen.
Israel’s king pursued the Arameans, defeating their horses and chariots, crushing many Arameans.
The prophet approached Israel’s king.
In the spring of the year, Ben-hadad assembled the Arameans and waged war against Israel at Aphek.

All the Israelites assembled and prepared and went out to meet the Arameans for battle. The camp of the Israelites looked like two tiny herds of goats compared to the Aramean army which filled the entire land.
A man of God approached Israel’s king.
They camped out across from each other for seven days; and when the seventh day arrived, the battle began. The Israelites crushed 100,000 Aramean warriors in a single day.
All those who escaped ran into the city of Aphek. A great wall collapsed on them and killed 27,000 men. Ben-hadad escaped to the city and hid himself in a secret chamber.
The servants dressed accordingly. They put sackcloth around their waists and ropes around their heads; then they approached Israel’s king.
The servants watched carefully and perceived this to be a sign, and they replied with surprise.
By the word of the Eternal, one of the prophets’ sons made a request to another man.
The prophet left and waited on the side of the road for the king to come by. The prophet bandaged his eyes with a cloth, so that the king would not recognize him.
As soon as the king was near, the prophet shouted.
The prophet then removed the cloth from his eyes, and Israel’s king recognized him as one of the prophets.
Israel’s king, frustrated and bad-tempered, returned to his house in Samaria.
